title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: {{quote box|width=30%|"My most fervent wish is that I will not be replaced until a new president is installed."| —Ginsburg, dictated to her granddaughter.<ref name="last">{{Cite web |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/09/ruth-bader-ginsburg-rbg-dying-wish.html |last=Stahl |first=Jeremy |date=September 18, 2020 |accessdate=September 18, 2020 |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |lang=en-US |title=RBG's Dying Words: 'My Most Fervent Wish Is That I Not Be Replaced Until a New President Is Installed' |archive-date=September 19, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919035253/https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/09/ruth-bader-ginsburg-rbg-dying-wish.html |url-status=live }}</ref>}}

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Ginsburg's death left eight Supreme Court justices split 4–4 between characteristically conservative and characteristically liberal, during a [[2020 United States presidential election|presidential election year]]. According to a [[National Public Radio]] report, prior to Ginsburg's death, she said to her granddaughter, "My most fervent wish is that I will not be replaced until a new president is installed."<ref>https://www.npr.org/2020/09/18/100306972/justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-champion-of-gender-equality-dies-at-87</ref> U.S. Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell vowed to bring a Trump nominee to replace Ginsburg to a vote in the Senate, arguing in part that "Since the 1880s, no Senate has confirmed an opposite-party president's Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year."<ref>https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/mcconnell-statement-on-the-passing-of-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: Ginsburg died from complications of pancreatic cancer on September 18, 2020, at age 87.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|date=September 18, 2020|title=Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Dies at 87|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-dies-at-87.html|access-date=September 19, 2020|issn=0362-4331|url-access=registration|archive-date=September 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919000041/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-dies-at-87.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Sherman|first=Mark|date=September 18, 2020|title=Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg dies of metastatic pancreatic cancer |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/09/18/nation/supreme-court-says-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-has-died-metastatic-pancreatic-cancer-age-87/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919004312/https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/09/18/nation/supreme-court-says-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-has-died-metastatic-pancreatic-cancer-age-87/|archive-date=September 19, 2020|access-date=September 19, 2020|website=The Boston Globe|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="NPR death"/> One day before her death, Ginsburg was honored on [[Constitution Day (United States)|Constitution Day]] and was awarded the 2020 Liberty Medal by the [[National Constitution Center]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Receives 2020 Liberty Medal During Virtual Event|language=en-US|work=[[KYW-TV|CBS 3]]|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/09/17/supreme-court-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-receives-2020-liberty-medal-during-virtual-event/|date=September 17, 2020|access-date=September 18, 2020|url-status=live|archive-date=September 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919035249/https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/09/17/supreme-court-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-receives-2020-liberty-medal-during-virtual-event/}}</ref> It was reported that she will be interred in [[Arlington National Cemetery]] next to her husband [[Martin D. Ginsburg]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Hallemann|first=Caroline|date=September 19, 2020|title=All the Details on Ruth Bader Ginsburg's Funeral|work=Town & Country|url=https://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/politics/a34081074/ruth-bader-ginsberg-funeral-details/|url-status=live|access-date=September 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200919010751/https://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/politics/a34081074/ruth-bader-ginsberg-funeral-details/|archive-date=September 19, 2020}}</ref> Following her death, over $20 million was donated to various [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] politicians via [[ActBlue]], more than quintuple the previous record amount.<ref>{{Cite news |date=September 18, 2020 |title=Democrats shatter the ActBlue site's donation records in the hours after Ginsburg's death, more than quintuple the previous record amount. |author=Goldmacher, Shane|work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/elections/democrats-shatter-the-actblue-sites-donation-records-in-the-hours-after-ginsburgs-death.html}}</ref>

According to a [[National Public Radio]] report, prior to Ginsburg's death, she said to her granddaughter, "My most fervent wish is that I will not be replaced until a new president is installed."<ref>https://www.npr.org/2020/09/18/100306972/justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-champion-of-gender-equality-dies-at-87</ref> U.S. Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell vowed to bring a Trump nominee to replace Ginsburg to a vote in the Senate, arguing in part that "Since the 1880s, no Senate has confirmed an opposite-party president's Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year."<ref>https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/mcconnell-statement-on-the-passing-of-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: In 2009, Ginsberg received a Lifetime Acheivement Award from Scribes--The American Society of Legal Writers.<ref>https://www.scribes.org/lifetime-achievement-award</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: Following her appointment to the Supreme Court in 1993,{{cn|date=September 2020}} Ginsburg deviated from the traditional American [[court dress]] by wearing a French ''robe d'avocat'',<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rosemont|first=Sophie|date=September 19, 2020|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg, l'icône|trans-title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the icon|url=https://www.rollingstone.fr/ruth-bader-ginsburg-la-femme-debout/|url-status=live|access-date=September 19, 2020|website=Rolling Stone|language=fr-FR}}</ref> as opposed to the typical judicial robe worn in the United States. The French robe differs from the American with its exposed buttons, open sleeves, standing collar, and white [[rabat]]. On the left shoulder of the robe are two buttons intended for the fastening of an [[epitoge]], traditionally worn by French lawyers. In later years, Ginsburg shifted from the traditionally uniform white French rabat and began wearing more varied and fanciful [[jabot (neckwear)|jabot]]s, necklaces, and other forms of neckwear. Some time later, fellow Supreme Court justice Sandra Day O'Connor and other women on the court followed Ginsburg's lead and began wearing the French ''robe d'avocat'' as well.{{cn|date=September 2020}}

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Shortly after speaking at a rally in [[Bemidji, Minnesota|Bemidji]], [[Minnesota]], U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] reacted to her death, stating: "She led an amazing life... ...whether you agreed or not, she was an amazing woman who led an amazing life".<ref>{{Cite web|title=User Clip: President Trump Upon Hearing of Justice Ginsburg Death {{!}} C-SPAN.org|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4907546/user-clip-president-trump-hearing-justice-ginsburg-death|access-date=2020-09-20|website=www.c-span.org|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Kaplan|first=Thomas|last2=Karni|first2=Annie|date=2020-09-18|title=News of Justice Ginsburg’s Death Arrives as Biden and Trump Host Dueling Minnesota Events|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/politics/joe-biden-trump-minnesota.html|access-date=2020-09-20|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: Shortly after speaking at a rally in [[Bemidji, Minnesota|Bemidji]], [[Minnesota]], U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] reacted to her death, stating: "She led an amazing life... ...whether you agreed [with her] or not, she was an amazing woman who led an amazing life".<ref>{{Cite web|title=User Clip: President Trump Upon Hearing of Justice Ginsburg Death {{!}} C-SPAN.org|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4907546/user-clip-president-trump-hearing-justice-ginsburg-death|access-date=2020-09-20|website=www.c-span.org|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Kaplan|first=Thomas|last2=Karni|first2=Annie|date=2020-09-18|title=News of Justice Ginsburg’s Death Arrives as Biden and Trump Host Dueling Minnesota Events|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/18/us/politics/joe-biden-trump-minnesota.html|access-date=2020-09-20|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
deleted: Others on the contrary view this date of passing and age at death (87 equalling the days in three lunar months when a fetus generally starts to show) as divine recompense especially vis a vis her expansion of abortion.[http://naanaach.blogspot.com/2020/09/justice-for-rbg-on-rosh-hashana.html?m=1]

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Ginsburg will lie in state at the Capital. She will be the first Jewish person and the first woman to do so. <ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-09-21|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg will be the first Jew and first woman to lie in state at the Capitol|url=https://www.jta.org/2020/09/21/united-states/ruth-bader-ginsburg-will-be-the-first-jew-and-first-woman-to-lie-in-state-at-the-capitol|access-date=2020-09-21|website=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: In light of the mounting backlog in the federal judiciary, Congress passed the [[Omnibus Judgeship Act of 1978]] increasing the number of federal judges by 117 in district courts and another 35 to be added to the circuit courts. The law placed an emphasis on ensuring that the judges included women and minority groups, a matter that was important to President [[Jimmy Carter]] who had been elected two years before. The bill also required that the nomination process consider the character and experience of the candidates.{{Sfn|De Hart|2020|p=277}} Ginsburg was considering a change in career as soon as Carter was elected. She was interviewed by the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] to become [[Solicitor General of the United States|Solicitor General]], the position she most desired, but knew that she and the African-American candidate who was interviewed the same day had little chance of being appointed by Attorney General [[Griffin Bell]].{{Sfn|De Hart|2020|p=278}}

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
added: Besides ''Grutter'', Ginsburg wrote in favor of affirmative action in her dissent in ''[[Gratz v. Bollinger]]'' (2003), in which the court ruled an affirmative action policy unconstitutional because it was not [[Strict scrutiny|narrowly tailored]] to the state's interest in diversity. She argued that "government decisionmakers may properly distinguish between policies of exclusion and inclusion...Actions designed to burden groups long denied full citizenship stature are not sensibly ranked with measures taken to hasten the day when entrenched discrimination and its after effects have been extirpated."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heriot |first1=Gail |title=Thoughts on Grutter v. Bollinger and Gratz v. Bollinger as Law and as Practical Politics |journal=[[Loyola University Chicago Law Journal]] |date=2004 |volume=36 |page=137 |url=https://lawecommons.luc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1246&context=luclj |accessdate=September 26, 2020}}</ref>
